"Just because someone stumbles and loses their way doesn't mean they're lost forever." That's a quote from the latest X-Men movie, X-Men: Days of Future Past. Interestingly enough, those words could also apply to the film's director, Bryan Singer. He's a talented guy, but once upon a time, Singer lost his way.

The comic book movie age of today actually started 14 years ago, and Bryan Singer deserves a lot of the credit. He came out with X-Men in 2000. At the time it was a new take on comic book movies. Prior to X-Men, most (or all) were campy, poorly made, or both. But in X-Men, the tone was darker, the production quality was higher, it was more grounded in reality and the movie took itself seriously. And this was clear from the beginning. The film cast serious talent, and its opening scene was in Nazi-occupied Poland after all. It was well received by critics and audiences alike, and it became the patriarch of the comic book movie age.

A few years after X-Men, Singer came out with its sequel, X2: X-Men United. It was also well received by critics and audiences. Singer started work on a third installment, but then left the film to work on Superman Returns. That decision is where he stumbled and lost his way, because Superman and X-Men both suffered in the process. Superman Returns was not successful enough to reboot that franchise, and X-Men: The Last Stand was viewed as a disappointment by pretty much everyone. It didn't get any better from there either. After The Last Stand came X-Men Origins: Wolverine, also a disappointment.

The X-Men series didn't die, though, and it didn't reboot itself either. It just started making better movies, starting with X-Men: First Class, and then with The Wolverine. But no X-Men film since X2 has had Singer in the director's chair. Even with First Class turning around the series in a positive way, many have been yearning for Singer to return, believing he has an understanding of the material that others do not. In the latest installment, Days of Future Past, Singer returns to the director's chair in what is billed as the biggest X-Men film yet. There is a ton of hype around this film. As a general rule fanboys (of anything) kind of bother me, but are they right this time around? Does Singer really have 'The Midas Touch' when it comes to the X-Men? Is it worth all the hype?

Full disclosure, I like the X-Men. There are really only two types of guys - those who like comic books and those who lie. Growing up, I never really got into Superman, Spiderman or Batman. It was X-Men for me, thanks to its Saturday morning cartoon, so if there was only one movie I was looking forward to this year, this would be it. I'm not unbiased, but I'll do my best to still be fair.

That wasn't the shortest prologue of all time, so let's get right to it. Should you see X-Men: Days of Future Past? This is an easy one.. Yes! To the uninitiated, it's good. The production quality is great. Its story is good and interesting, its cast is great, and you needn't have seen the other six films to enjoy it. To fans of X-Men (even those with just a passing interest), it is great. Fanboys were right about Singer, and Days of Future Past more than validates their strong desire for his return. I'm not exactly sure of the best way to articulate this point, but he just makes everything fit together in a way that no one else has in the X-Men universe. This is the seventh film in the franchise, and somehow Singer was able to tie all six prior films together, which is an unbelievable achievement.

Some might scratch their head at what I just said, thinking this is only the fifth X-Men installment, but it really is the seventh because the Wolverine movies count too. With the exception of First Class, Wolverine is the main character of every film. He is the only character to be in all seven films (unless you count the post-credits scene of The Wolverine, in which case Xavier has also been in all seven films). In the X-Men film universe, there are really only three characters that have significant character arcs - Xavier, Magneto and Wolverine. First Class built on the character arcs of the Xavier and Magneto, but every other film was way more about Wolverine than anyone else. In Days of Future Past, Singer combined the arcs of all three in a sensible and satisfying way. And he even threw in a bunch of small stuff that enriches the movie further. For instance, Wolverine had one line in First Class, and Singer was even able to pull that into this story in a way that made sense.

Let's talk about what this movie is actually about. In the X-Men universe, there are people with special powers, and they are not so affectionately known as "mutants." Many "normal" people fear mutants, for the simple reason that people fear what they do not understand. One of the staples of the comics are "Sentinels" - giant robots that hunt mutants. Sentinels were teased in The Last Stand in two ways - you saw the head of a Sentinel after Wolverine decapitated it in a combat simulation, and Boliver Trask (the creator of the Sentinels) had a small role in the film. Both teases were unsatisfying and didn't give the staple its due justice. Other than that, there have been no Sentinels in the X-Men films. Until Days of Future Past, that is, which is all about Sentinels - Sentinels in the past, Sentinels in the future, they're everywhere.

The film starts in a post-apocalyptic future where mutants have lost everything. They've either been killed or placed in mutant internment camps. There are still some familiar mutants, but their days are numbered. One of those familiar mutants is Wolverine, who finds a way to transfer his consciousness back in time to his younger self. The plan is to stop the Sentinel program in the past so it never grows to wipe out mutants in the future. Wolverine can't do this alone, though, so once he is in the past he must bring the X-Men together to stop the war from ever starting.

The best part about this movie is the characters and the relationships between them. The acting is great and they play off of each other very well. As mentioned earlier, the X-Men series didn't do a reboot even after it produced a few duds, and it didn't need to. Even throughout the duds, the character arcs that took place were good enough to keep the series going. Also, it would be quite difficult (or impossible) to find a better Logan/Wolverine that Hugh Jackman and a better Xavier/Professor X than Patrick Stewart. They kind of make the series un-reboot-able for the time being. In Days of Future Past, once again Wolverine is the main character, and Jackman is as good as ever in the role. If you read my review of The Wolverine, you know that I mentioned that one of its strong suits was how likeable Wolverine has become. I know I'm repeating myself here, but he's even more likeable this time around. Jackman has executed the character arc of Wolverine pretty flawlessly. He's always been a good guy, but when we first saw him in X-Men, he preferred being a lone wolf to being part of a team (and being a leader was certainly out of the question). He has grown quite a bit since then, though, to the point in Days of Future Past where he, not Xavier, is leading the X-Men. It's very interesting to see this play out on the big screen, and Jackman deserves a ton of credit here. Even as Logan has grown, he has not lost the essence of what makes him The Wolverine.

There are literally too many stars in this film to go through one-by-one, so I'll cover most of them with a blanket statement that everyone does a nice job. The other most notable ones are James McAvoy as the young Xavier, Michael Fassbender as the young Magneto and Jennifer Lawrence as Mystique. McAvoy does a great job and gives us a side of Xavier than we've never seen before. Fassbender is once again great as Magento. As a character, Magneto has always been somewhat likeable and somewhat unlikeable. He is more unlikeable in this one than he was in First Class, but I think he's supposed to be and you still understand his motivations which is key. And the contrast between him and the older Magneto (Ian McKellan) helps to make Magneto pretty likeable in the future. The character of Mystique has a large role in this film, which is great because it means we get to see Jennifer Lawrence wearing nothing but blue body paint for a good portion of the film. But it's also good because she does a nice job in that role and you can feel the chemistry and tension between her and McAvoy.

Days of Future Past hasn't received much criticism and it shouldn't, but one area where there has been a little criticism is with the villain. Some critics seem to think that Boliver Trask is lacking as a villain, but this criticism isn't really fair. Peter Dinklage does a fine job in the role, so he's not the problem, but Trask isn't the problem either. We don't learn too much about Trask and he doesn't have a lot of screen time, but that's because he's not really the villain. He's not a great guy but is he really the villain? The Sentinels are more villainous than him, but they're not really the villain either. The real villain is fear. That may seem strange or abstract, but what our heros are really fighting against is fear and what people and mutants do when they are afraid. The film is about facing fear and rising above it, which is why criticizing Trask doesn't make too much sense.

The tone of this movie is also very good. It's dark, but not too dark, and takes itself seriously. There is also some pretty good comedy in this movie. It works because it's situational and not slapstick, and it is usually born out of the relationships between characters. It does not detract from the seriousness of the movie. The pacing isn't bad but I wouldn't say it's great. I think Singer is a talented guy, but pacing has never been his strongest suit. He likes to build things up and allow them to develop (which is a good thing), but in comparison to what audiences are used to, it may seem to be a little slow at times. Overall this isn't a bad thing, because it means he's not throwing in action for the sake of action. At the same time, to be fair I must mention that some films do a better job with pacing while still allowing things to develop (Batman Begins and Iron Man come to mind). Fast or slow, there are a lot of nice scenes in this movie. There is powerful dialogue and good use of voice-overs.

One thing that is abundantly clear upon leaving the theater is that the future of the X-Men film series has never looked brighter. Singer has made a very good movie here, and because he was able to pull together all the prior stories, the duds of the series should be a little more palatable since now we can see that they ultimately lead to something greater. I imagine now the focus will primarily be on what is to come, instead of on things like remembering how much they fucked up Deadpool in X-Men Origins. There have been a few continuity problems in the X-Men film series. In The Last Stand, Boliver Trask was a big black guy. In Days of Future Past, he's a little white guy who Buddy The Elf thinks ran away from the North Pole. But that's small stuff which is forgivable if you get the big stuff right. In fact, this movie totally ignores some of the smaller stuff which is fine. Things like, how is Xavier alive? Watch the post-credits scene of The Last Stand if you really want to know. How does Wolverine have metal claws again? Who cares? He's buddies with Magneto now, so use your imagination. The point is that neither of those things actually matter to this movie. By not wasting time on the small stuff, Singer made sure to keep the main thing the main thing. As a whole, the series has always gotten the big stuff right, which is to say they got Professor X, Magneto and Wolverine right.

As for Days of Future Past, it gets just about everything right. See this movie! This is quite possibly the best film in the X-Men franchise. I'm having a hard time deciding if it's the best comic book movie of the year. Both it and Captain America: The Winter Soldier are very good, if not great. I'm going to give the nod to X-Men, but like I said earlier, I'm biased.
